The , or 'JSDF', occasionally referred to as 'JSF' or 'SDF', are the unified
military forces of Japan that were established after the end of the postâWorld
War II Allied occupation of Japan. For most of the post-war period the JSDF was
confined to the islands of Japan and not permitted to be deployed abroad. In
recent years they have been engaged in international peacekeeping
operations. Recent tensions, particularly with North
Korea, have reignited the debate over the status of the JSDF and its
relation to Japanese society. Retrieved: October 25, 2010 New
military guidelines, announced in December 2010, will direct the Jieitai away
from its Cold War focus on the Soviet Union to a focus on China, especially
regarding the dispute over the Senkaku Islands. {{cite news
| last= Fackler first= Martin url=
| http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/17/world/asia/17japan.html title= Japan
| Announces Defense Policy to Counter China publisher= The New York Times date=
| December 16, 2010 accessdate= December 17, 2010}}
